> I've been hacking away at a simple OCR demo using DelphiNEAT. I let NEAT
> see a picture (7 x 14 pixels) of a letter and let it choose which letter
> it thinks it is (out of 26 letters). Thus, I have 7*14=98 inputs + 1
> bias. And I have 26 outputs. Creating a connection from every input to
> every output leads to 99*26 = 2574 connections per network.
>
> Now, I've tried a method where I add X random connections instead of the
> full 2574 connections, but so far, the results are depressing.
>
> Does anyone have an idea for a better method?

Hi Mattias,

I am working on a method that incorporates NEAT but allows for reuse of
sub-networks in constructing the solution networks. It is specifically
targetted to deal with some of the situations in which NEAT performs
poorly (decision tasks with large input/output spaces, etc). While it is
more useful for processing tasks that can be parallelized in the input or
output space, it may be useful in an OCR type situation as well (which
relies more on combining data from disparate parts of the input space).

Modular NEAT starts out similar to how you describe with X random
connections, but these connections actually represet modules that can
expand in complexity and be reused across the space of the solution
network. The network grows new connections as needed and the optimal
combination of what modules where is worked out during evolution.

I've done some tests with board games of sizes 7x7 (full NEAT: 2401
connections) and 10x10 (full NEAT: 10000 connections) and the results
appear promising.

The code is very very rough (nowhere near as documented as NEAT) but if
it sounds interesting to you, let me know.

Joe
